name: n-amyl acetate
Reason: To predict the melting point of n-amyl acetate, consider the effects of the functional groups involved. The basic unit we can use as a reference is ethyl acetate, which has a melting point of -83.6 °C. Adding additional carbon atoms increases the molecular weight and surface area, which typically raises the melting point. Each additional methylene (CH2) group in a linear alkane chain increases the melting point by approximately 2 °C. n-Amyl acetate has three more CH2 groups than ethyl acetate (C2H5COOCH3). Also, the ester functional group (COO) generally has a lower melting point than a similar alkane because of the polar nature of the ester group enabling better packing compared to nonpolar alkanes. However, the elongation of the carbon chain could counterbalance the ester effect due to the increase in van der Waals forces. Since our base reference is already an ester, the main consideration will be the alkyl chain length.
Prediction: For n-amyl acetate, taking ethyl acetate as the reference (melting point -83.6°C) and adding the effect of the three additional CH2 groups: 3 CH2 x 2 °C/CH2 = +6°C, we get the predicted melting point of -83.6 °C + 6 °C = -77.6 °C. This prediction is close to the actual value of -70.8 °C, which suggests that there could be additional contributing factors such as conformational flexibility of the longer alkyl chain that may slightly raise the melting point beyond the additive effect of methylene groups.
